DOC.HEAD: Government Lending Agency Fails To Serve Consumers, Nader Group Says
DOC.TEXT: A little-known government agency created 11 years ago to lend money to cooperative organizations has failed to adequately serve consumers since it was privatized by the Reagan Administration in 1982, a group affiliated with activist Ralph Nader charged Monday. The Nader group, Center for Study of Responsive Law, charged at a news conference that the National Cooperative Bank has in effect used the subsidy from a low-interest $184.3 million federal loan to provide the profits necessary pay its executives high salaries and provide financial benefits to large cooperatives serving small businesses rather than consumers. In 1988, only 5 percent of the bank's 641 member cooperatives served businesses rather than individuals, yet 30 percent of the bank's $199.6 milion in disbursements during the year were to the business cooperatives, even though the law limits lending to business cooperatives at 10 percent of the total, according to a report prepared for the Nader group by Seyoum A. Haregot. The report also claimed the bank is not doing enough to serve low-income consumers or to stimulate the formation of new cooperatives. Nader, in a forward to the report, said bank has abandoned its ``one-cooperative, one vote'' principle in favor of a voting system that gives control of the organization to large, established cooperatives. He said the bank's managers drove it from ``serving ultimate consumers and toward a commercial banking model replete with executive emoluments, all the while enjoying its substantial taxpayer subsidy.'' The federal subsidy to the bank totaled $119.5 million from 1982 through 1988, according to Haregot's report. Salaries, benefits and bonuses to the bank's nine top executives totaled $1.3 million in 1988, including $250,000 to Thomas S. Condit, president and chief executive officer of the bank, the report said. In a written response, Linda R. Lewis, corporate vice president of the bank, said the salaries were in line with the pay of other financial institutions and said the bank has not been obligated to keep its pay comparable to government salaries since its privatization. She said the bank disagreed with Haregot's argument that it lent too heavily to business-owned cooperatives, saying that ``we believe a cooperative owned by a business is in fact owned by ultimate consumers.'' Also, the bank, at mid-1989, had a low-income loan portfolio of $131.8 million, she said. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said he was ``deeply concerned'' about the ``failed promise'' of the bank and said it would be ``placed on the oversight agenda of the committee.''
